sub_topic: Probability of a certain type of entertainment outcome occurring in a performance.
message_1: A circus performance has 10 different acts, and each act has a 0.2 probability of involving acrobats. What is the probability that at least 2 of the acts will involve acrobats?
message_2:
To find the probability of at least 2 acts involving acrobats, we can use the complementary probability, which is the probability of 0 or 1 act involving acrobats. 

Probability of 0 acts involving acrobats:
Each act has a 0.8 probability of not involving acrobats (1 - 0.2 = 0.8).
P(0 acts) = 0.8^10 ≈ 0.1074

Probability of 1 act involving acrobats:
We can use the binomial probability formula: P(x) = C(n, x) * p^x * (1-p)^(n-x)
where n = 10 (total acts), x = 1 (number of acts involving acrobats), p = 0.2 (probability of an act involving acrobats), and C(n, x) is the number of combinations of n items taken x at a time.

C(10, 1) = 10 (10 ways to choose 1 act out of 10)
P(1 act) = 10 * 0.2^1 * 0.8^9 ≈ 0.2684

Now, we can find the complementary probability:
P(at least 2 acts) = 1 - P(0 acts) - P(1 act) ≈ 1 - 0.1074 - 0.2684 ≈ 0.6242

So, the probability that at least 2 of the acts will involve acrobats is approximately 0.6242 or 62.42%.
